titleInfo.title: Handwritten statement to accompany return of ordnance and ordnance stores

mods.abstract: Statement makes reference to arms and ammunition damaged by wet weather during the battle with Hood at Nashville on December 15 - 18, 1864. From Company F, 7th Regiment of Quartermaster's Forces, Nashville, for the second quarter ending June 30, 1865.
mods.accessCondition: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.

relatedItem.identifier: Statement to accompany Return of Ordnance and Ordnance Stores under charge of Capt. W. A. Wainwright A. Q. M. for Company “F” 7th Regiment of Quartermasters Forces Nashville Tenn. For the 2nd Quarter ending June 30th 1865. The Ordnance Property taken up on this Return was “unserviceable” & Dropped was rendered unserviceable from no neglect of those having it in charge-during the battle with Hood at Nashville on the 15th-16th-17th & 18th Dec. 1864. The Muskets & Accoutrements were old & much worn when first Received and as the “Quartermaster’s Forces” were ordered out with both arms and intrenching tools. The Arms and Ammunition were unavoidably damaged by the wet weather while the Forces were hurriedly throwing up intrenchments. The 3000 Cartridges received from Capt. C. H. Irvin A. Q. M. as per Invoice dated Dec. 20th 1864 were invoiced as B. & B. Cal. Cg – But on examination were found to be only 1000 B. & B. Cal. Cg. & the other 2000 were E. B. Cartridges Cal. 574 and as such are taken up and dropped on Return. I certify the above Statement to be Correct. W. A. Wainright Capt. A. Q. M.

titleInfo.title: William Alonzo Wainwright, United States Assistant Quartermaster Records, 1861-1870

relatedItem.abstract: The images found in this section have been gathered from various manuscript collections and offer a glimpse at the wide variety of material available at the Tennessee State Library and Archives that may be of interest to those researching Civil War history and genealogy. These images illustrate the extensive recordkeeping system at work during the Civil War and demonstrate the complex organizational structure needed to handle the massive accumulation of records. From transportation orders to quartermaster records, these items not only provide insight into the soldiers’ lives, they also illustrate the costs of war and sacrifices that were made from all facets of society on both the Confederate and Federal sides...

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Record has been transformed into MODS 3.5 from a qualified Dublin Core record by the Digital Library of Tennessee, a service hub of the Digital Public Library of America, using a stylesheet available at https://github.com/utkdigitalinitiatives/DLTN.
